The Armenian conquest of Judea was a short military campaign in which the Armenian king Tigranes the Great brought Judea under his control during the early 1st century BC.
Background
In the 1st century BC, the Armenian Empire under Tigranes II reached its greatest territorial extent. Following the collapse of the Seleucid Empire, Tigranes expanded southwards into Mesopotamia, Syria, and Phoenicia.
At this time, Judea under the Hasmonean dynasty was weakened by dynastic conflicts, making it vulnerable to foreign domination.
Campaign
Around 83–82 BC, Tigranes invaded Syria and advanced into Judea. According to Josephus (Antiquities of the Jews, XIII.418–419), the Hasmonean rulers surrendered, acknowledged Armenian supremacy, and agreed to pay tribute. Armenian garrisons may have been stationed in the region.
Aftermath
The Armenian hold over Judea lasted only a few decades. During the Third Mithridatic War, Roman generals Lucullus and Pompey defeated Tigranes (69–66 BC), forcing him to abandon his conquests. Judea soon came under Roman influence, ending the short-lived Armenian domination.
Primary sources
